1.1: All wisdom comes from the Lord,
1.2: Who can count the sand of the seas,
1.3: Who will search out the height of the sky,
1.4: Wisdom has been created before all things,
1.6: To whom has the root of wisdom been revealed?
1.8: There is one wise, greatly to be feared,
1.10: She is with all flesh according to his gift.
1.11: The fear of the Lord is glory, exultation,
1.12: The fear of the Lord will delight the heart,
1.13: Whoever fears the Lord, it will go well with him at the last.
1.14: To fear the Lord is the beginning of wisdom.
1.15: She laid an eternal foundation with men.
1.16: To fear the Lord is the fullness of wisdom.
1.17: She will fill all her house with desirable things,
1.18: The fear of the Lord is the crown of wisdom,
1.19: He both saw and measured her.
1.20: To fear the Lord is the root of wisdom.
1.22: Unjust wrath can never be justified,
1.23: A man that is patient will resist for a season,
1.24: He will hide his words until the right moment,
1.25: A wise saying is in the treasures of wisdom;
1.26: If you desire wisdom, keep the commandments
1.27: for the fear of the Lord is wisdom and instruction.
1.28: Don’t disobey the fear of the Lord.
1.29: Don’t be a hypocrite in men’s sight.

2.1: My son, if you come to serve the Lord,
2.2: Set your heart aright, constantly endure,
2.3: Cling to him, and don’t depart,
2.4: Accept whatever is brought upon you,
2.5: For gold is tried in the fire,
2.6: Put your trust in him, and he will help you.
2.7: All you who fear the Lord, wait for his mercy.
2.8: All you who fear the Lord, put your trust in him,
2.9: All you who fear the Lord, hope for good things,
2.10: Look at the generations of old, and see:
2.11: For the Lord is full of compassion and mercy.
2.12: Woe to fearful hearts, to faint hands,
2.13: Woe to the faint heart! For it doesn’t believe.
2.14: Woe to you who have lost your patience!
2.15: Those who fear the Lord will not disobey his words.
2.16: Those who fear the Lord will seek his good pleasure.
2.17: Those who fear the Lord will prepare their hearts,
2.18: We will fall into the hands of the Lord,

3.1: Hear me, your father, O my children,
3.2: For the Lord honors the father over the children,
3.3: He who honors his father will make atonement for sins.
3.4: He who gives glory to his mother is as one who lays up treasure.
3.5: Whoever honors his father will have joy in his own children.
3.6: He who gives glory to his father will have length of days.
3.7: and will serve under his parents, as to masters.
3.8: Honor your father in deed and word,
3.9: For the blessing of the father establishes the houses of children,
3.10: Don’t glorify yourself in the dishonor of your father,
3.11: For the glory of a man is from the honor of his father,
3.12: My son, help your father in his old age,
3.13: If he fails in understanding, have patience with him.
3.14: For the kindness to your father will not be forgotten.
3.15: In the day of your affliction it will be remembered for you,
3.16: He who forsakes his father is as a blasphemer.
3.17: My son, go on with your business in humility;
3.18: The greater you are, humble yourself the more,
3.20: For the power of the Lord is great,
3.21: Don’t seek things that are too hard for you,
3.22: Think about the things that have been commanded you,
3.23: Don’t be overly busy in tasks that are beyond you,
3.24: For the conceit of many has led them astray.
3.25: There is no light without eyes.
3.26: A stubborn heart will do badly at the end.
3.27: A stubborn heart will be burdened with troubles.
3.28: The calamity of the proud has no healing,
3.29: The heart of the prudent will understand a proverb.
3.30: Water will quench a flaming fire;
3.31: He who repays good turns is mindful of that which comes afterward.

4.1: My son, don’t deprive the poor of his living.
4.2: Don’t make a hungry soul sorrowful,
4.3: Don’t add more trouble to a heart that is provoked.
4.4: Don’t reject a suppliant in his affliction.
4.5: Don’t turn your eye away from one who asks.
4.6: For if he curses you in the bitterness of his soul,
4.8: Incline your ear to a poor man.
4.9: Deliver him who is wronged from the hand of him who wrongs him;
4.10: Be as a father to the fatherless,
4.12: He who loves her loves life.
4.13: He who holds her fast will inherit glory.
4.14: Those who serve her minister to the Holy One.
4.15: He who listens to her will judge the nations.
4.16: If he trusts her, he will inherit her,
4.17: For at the first she will walk with him in crooked ways,
4.18: Then she will return him again to the straight way,
4.19: If he goes astray, she will forsake him,
4.20: Watch for the opportunity, and beware of evil.
4.21: For there is a shame that brings sin,
4.22: Don’t show partiality, discrediting your soul.
4.23: Don’t refrain from speaking when it is for safety.
4.24: For wisdom will be known by speech,
4.26: Don’t be ashamed to confess your sins.
4.27: Don’t lay yourself down for a fool to tread upon.
4.28: Strive for the truth to death,
4.29: Don’t be hasty with your tongue,
4.30: Don’t be like a lion in your house,
4.31: Don’t let your hand be stretched out to receive,

5.1: Don’t set your heart upon your goods.
5.2: Don’t follow your own mind and your strength
5.3: Don’t say, “Who will have dominion over me?”
5.4: Don’t say, “I sinned, and what happened to me?”
5.5: Don’t be so confident of atonement
5.7: Don’t wait to turn to the Lord.
5.8: Don’t set your heart upon unrighteous gains,
5.12: If you have understanding, answer your neighbor;
5.13: Glory and dishonor is in talk.
5.15: Don’t be ignorant in a great or small matter.

6.1: Don’t become an enemy instead of a friend;
6.2: Don’t exalt yourself in the counsel of your soul,
6.3: You will eat up your leaves, destroy your fruit,
6.4: A wicked soul will destroy him who has it,
6.5: Sweet words will multiply a man’s friends.
6.6: Let those that are at peace with you be many,
6.7: If you want to gain a friend, get him in a time of testing,
6.8: For there is a friend just for an occasion.
6.9: And there is a friend who turns into an enemy.
6.10: And there is a friend who is a companion at the table,
6.11: In your prosperity he will be as yourself,
6.12: If you are brought low, he will be against you,
6.14: A faithful friend is a strong defense.
6.15: There is nothing that can be taken in exchange for a faithful friend.
6.16: A faithful friend is a life-saving medicine.
6.17: He who fears the Lord directs his friendship properly;
6.18: My son, gather instruction from your youth up.
6.19: Come to her as one who plows and sows
6.20: How exceedingly harsh she is to the unlearned!
6.21: She will rest upon him as a mighty stone of trial.
6.22: For wisdom is according to her name.
6.23: Give ear, my son, and accept my judgment.
6.24: Bring your feet into her fetters,
6.25: Put your shoulder under her and bear her.
6.26: Come to her with all your soul.
6.27: Search and seek, and she will be made known to you.
6.28: For at the last you will find her rest;
6.29: Her fetters will be to you for a covering of strength,
6.30: For there is a golden ornament upon her,
6.31: You shall put her on as a robe of glory,
6.32: My son, if you are willing, you will be instructed.
6.33: If you love to hear, you will receive.
6.34: Stand in the multitude of the elders.
6.35: Be willing to listen to every godly discourse.
6.36: If you see a man of understanding, get to him early.
6.37: Let your mind dwell on the ordinances of the Lord

7.3: My son, don’t sow upon the furrows of unrighteousness,
7.4: Don’t seek preeminence from the Lord,
7.5: Don’t justify yourself in the presence of the Lord,
7.6: Don’t seek to be a judge,
7.7: Don’t sin against the multitude of the city.
7.9: Don’t say, “He will look upon the multitude of my gifts.
7.10: Don’t be faint-hearted in your prayer.
7.11: Don’t laugh a man to scorn when he is in the bitterness of his soul,
7.12: Don’t devise a lie against your brother,
7.14: Don’t babble in the assembly of elders.
7.16: Don’t number yourself among the multitude of sinners.
7.18: Don’t exchange a friend for something,
7.19: Don’t deprive yourself of a wise and good wife,
7.20: Don’t abuse a servant who works faithfully,
7.21: Let your soul love a wise servant.
7.22: Do you have cattle? Look after them.
7.23: Do you have children? Correct them,
7.24: Do you have daughters? Take care of their bodies,
7.25: Give your daughter in marriage, and you will have accomplished a great matter.
7.26: Do you have a wife who pleases you? Don’t cast her out.
7.27: Honor your father with your whole heart,
7.28: Remember that you were born of them.
7.29: Fear the Lord with all your soul;
7.30: With all your strength love him who made you.
7.31: Fear the Lord and honor the priest.
7.32: Also stretch out your hand to the poor man,
7.33: A gift has grace in the sight of every living man.
7.35: Don’t be slow to visit a sick man,
7.36: In all your words, remember eternity,

8.1: Don’t contend with a mighty man,
8.2: Don’t strive with a rich man, lest perhaps he overpower you;
8.3: Don’t argue with a loudmouthed man.
8.4: Don’t make fun of a rude man,
8.5: Don’t reproach a man when he turns from sin.
8.6: Don’t dishonor a man in his old age,
8.8: Don’t neglect the discourse of the wise.
8.9: Don’t miss the discourse of the aged,
8.10: Don’t kindle the coals of a sinner,
8.11: Don’t rise up from the presence of an insolent man,
8.12: Don’t lend to a man who is stronger than you;
8.13: Don’t be surety beyond your means.
8.14: Don’t go to law with a judge;
8.15: Don’t travel with a reckless man,
8.16: Don’t fight with a wrathful man.
8.18: Do no secret thing before a stranger,
8.19: Don’t open your heart to every man.

9.1: Don’t be jealous over the wife of your bosom,
9.2: Don’t give your soul to a woman
9.3: Don’t go to meet a woman who plays the prostitute,
9.4: Don’t associate with a woman who is a singer,
9.6: Don’t give your soul to prostitutes,
9.7: Don’t look around in the streets of the city.
9.8: Turn your eye away from a beautiful woman,
9.9: Don’t dine at all with a woman who has a husband,
9.11: Don’t envy the success of a sinner;
9.12: Don’t delight in the delights of the ungodly.
9.13: Keep yourself far from the man who has power to kill,
9.14: As well as you can, aim to know your neighbors,
9.15: Let your conversation be with men of understanding.
9.16: Let righteous people be companions at your table.
9.17: A work is commended because of the skill of the artisan;
9.18: A loudmouthed man is dangerous in his city.

10.1: A wise judge will instruct his people.
10.2: As is the judge of his people, so are his officials.
10.3: An undisciplined king will destroy his people.
10.4: The government of the earth is in the Lord’s hand.
10.5: A man’s prosperity is in the Lord’s hand.
10.6: Don’t be angry with your neighbor for every wrong.
10.7: Pride is hateful before the Lord and men.
10.8: Sovereignty is transferred from nation to nation
10.9: Why are dirt and ashes proud?
10.10: A long disease mocks the physician.
10.11: For when a man is dead,
10.12: It is the beginning of pride when a man departs from the Lord.
10.13: For the beginning of pride is sin.
10.14: The Lord cast down the thrones of rulers
10.15: The Lord plucked up the roots of nations
10.16: The Lord overthrew the lands of nations
10.17: He took some of them away and destroyed them,
10.18: Pride has not been created for men,
10.20: In the midst of kindred he who rules them has honor.
10.22: The rich man, the honorable, and the poor
10.23: It is not right to dishonor a poor man who has understanding.
10.24: The prince, the judge, and the mighty man will be honored.
10.25: Free men will minister to a wise servant.
10.26: Don’t flaunt your wisdom in doing your work.
10.27: Better is he who labors and abounds in all things,
10.28: My son, glorify your soul in humility,
10.29: Who will justify him who sins against his own soul?
10.30: A poor man is honored for his knowledge.
10.31: But he who is honored in poverty, how much more in riches?

11.1: The wisdom of the lowly will lift up his head,
11.2: Don’t commend a man for his good looks.
11.3: The bee is little among flying creatures,
11.4: Don’t boast about the clothes you wear,
11.5: Many kings have sat down upon the ground,
11.6: Many mighty men have been greatly disgraced.
11.8: Don’t answer before you have heard.
11.9: Don’t argue about a matter that doesn’t concern you.
11.10: My son, don’t be busy about many matters;
11.11: There is one who toils, labors, and hurries,
11.12: There is one who is sluggish, and needs help,
11.14: Good things and bad, life and death,
11.17: The Lord’s gift remains with the godly.
11.18: One grows rich by his diligence and self-denial,
11.19: when he says, “I have found rest,
11.20: Be steadfast in your covenant and be doing it,
11.21: Don’t marvel at the works of a sinner,
11.22: The Lord’s blessing is in the reward of the godly.
11.23: Don’t say, “What use is there of me?
11.25: In the day of good things, bad things are forgotten.
11.26: For it is an easy thing in the sight of the Lord
11.27: The affliction of an hour causes delights to be forgotten.
11.28: Call no man happy before his death.
11.29: Don’t bring every man into your house,
11.30: Like a decoy partridge in a cage, so is the heart of a proud man.
11.31: For he lies in wait to turn things that are good into evil,
11.32: From a spark of fire, a heap of many coals is kindled,
11.33: Take heed of an evil-doer, for he plans wicked things,
11.34: Receive a stranger into your house, and he will distract you with arguments

12.1: If you do good, know to whom you do it,
12.2: Do good to a godly man, and you will find a reward—
12.3: No good will come to him who continues to do evil,
12.5: Do good to one who is lowly.
12.6: For the Most High also hates sinners,
12.8: A man’s friend won’t be fully tried in prosperity.
12.9: In a man’s prosperity, his enemies are grieved.
12.11: Though he humbles himself and walks bowed down,
12.12: Don’t set him next to you,
12.13: Who will pity a charmer that is bitten by a snake,
12.14: Even so, who will pity him who goes to a sinner,
12.15: For a while he will stay with you,
12.16: The enemy will speak sweetly with his lips,
12.17: If adversity meets you, you will find him there before you.
12.18: He will shake his head, clap his hands,

13.1: He who touches pitch will be defiled.
13.2: Don’t take up a burden above your strength.
13.3: The rich man does a wrong and threatens.
13.4: If you are profitable, he will exploit you.
13.5: If you own something, he will live with you.
13.6: Does he need you? Then he will deceive you,
13.7: He will shame you by his delicacies
13.8: Beware that you are not deceived
13.9: If a mighty man invites you, be reserved,
13.10: Don’t press him, lest you be thrust back.
13.11: Don’t try to speak with him as an equal,
13.12: He who doesn’t keep secrets to himself is unmerciful.
13.13: Keep them to yourself and be careful,
13.15: Every living creature loves its own kind,
13.16: All flesh associates with their own kind.
13.17: What fellowship would the wolf have with the lamb?
13.18: What peace is there between a hyena and a dog?
13.19: Wild donkeys are the prey of lions in the wilderness;
13.20: Lowliness is an abomination to a proud man;
13.21: When a rich man is shaken, he is supported by his friends,
13.22: When a rich man falls, there are many helpers.
13.23: A rich man speaks, and all keep silence.
13.24: Riches are good if they have no sin.
13.25: The heart of a man changes his countenance,
13.26: A cheerful countenance is a sign of a prosperous heart.

14.1: Blessed is the man who has not slipped with his mouth,
14.2: Blessed is he whose soul does not condemn him,
14.3: Riches are not appropriate for a stingy person.
14.4: He who gathers by denying himself gathers for others.
14.5: If one is mean to himself, to whom will he be good?
14.6: There is none more evil than he who is grudging to himself.
14.7: Even if he does good, he does it in forgetfulness.
14.9: A covetous man’s eye is not satisfied with his portion.
14.11: My son, according to what you have, treat yourself well,
14.12: Remember that death will not wait,
14.13: Do good to your friends before you die.
14.14: Don’t deprive yourself of a good day.
14.15: Won’t you leave your labors to another,
14.16: Give, take, and treat yourself well,
14.17: All flesh grows old like a garment,
14.18: Like the leaves flourishing on a thick tree,
14.19: Every work rots and falls away,
14.20: Blessed is the man who meditates on wisdom,
14.21: He who considers her ways in his heart
14.22: Go after her like a hunter,
14.23: He who peers in at her windows
14.24: He who lodges close to her house
14.25: He will pitch his tent near at hand to her,
14.26: He will set his children under her shelter,
14.27: By her he will be covered from heat,

15.1: He who fears the Lord will do this.
15.2: She will meet him like a mother,
15.3: She will feed him with bread of understanding
15.4: He will be stayed upon her, and will not be moved.
15.5: She will exalt him above his neighbors.
15.6: He will inherit joy, a crown of gladness,
15.7: Foolish men will not obtain her.
15.9: Praise is not attractive in the mouth of a sinner;
15.10: For praise will be spoken in wisdom;
15.11: Don’t say, “It is through the Lord that I fell away;”
15.12: Don’t say, “It is he that caused me to err;”
15.14: He himself made man from the beginning
15.15: If you choose, you can keep the commandments.
15.16: He has set fire and water before you.
15.17: Before man is life and death.
15.18: For the wisdom of the Lord is great.
15.19: His eyes are upon those who fear him.
15.20: He has not commanded any man to be ungodly.

16.1: Don’t desire a multitude of unprofitable children,
16.2: If they multiply, don’t delight in them
16.4: For from one who has understanding, a city will be populated,
16.5: I have seen many such things with my eyes.
16.6: In a congregation of sinners, a fire will be kindled.
16.7: He was not pacified toward the giants of old time,
16.9: He didn’t pity the people of perdition
16.10: or in like manner, the six hundred thousand footmen
16.11: Even if there is one stiff-necked person,
16.12: As his mercy is great, so is his correction also.
16.13: The sinner will not escape with plunder.
16.14: He will make room for every work of mercy.
16.17: Don’t say, “I will be hidden from the Lord,”
16.18: Behold, heaven, the heaven of heavens,
16.19: The mountains and the foundations of the earth together
16.20: No heart will think about these things.
16.21: Like a tempest which no man can see,
16.22: Who will declare his works of righteousness?
16.23: He who is lacking in understanding thinks about these things.
16.24: My son, listen to me, learn knowledge,
16.25: I will impart instruction with precision,
16.26: In the judgment of the Lord are his works from the beginning.
16.27: He arranged his works for all time,
16.28: No one pushes aside his neighbor.
16.29: After this also the Lord looked at the earth
16.30: All manner of living things covered its surface,

17.1: The Lord created mankind out of earth,
17.2: He gave them days by number, and a set time,
17.3: He endowed them with strength proper to them,
17.4: He put the fear of man upon all flesh,
17.6: He gave them counsel, tongue, eyes,
17.7: He filled them with the knowledge of wisdom,
17.8: He set his eye upon their hearts,
17.10: And they will praise his holy name,
17.12: He made an everlasting covenant with them,
17.13: Their eyes saw the majesty of his glory.
17.14: He said to them, “Beware of all unrighteousness.”
17.15: Their ways are ever before him.
17.17: For every nation he appointed a ruler,
17.19: All their works are as clear as the sun before him.
17.20: Their iniquities are not hidden from him.
17.22: With him the alms of a man is as a signet.
17.23: Afterwards he will rise up and repay them,
17.24: However to those who repent he grants a return.
17.25: Return to the Lord, and forsake sins.
17.26: Turn again to the Most High, and turn away from iniquity.
17.27: Who will give praise to the Most High in Hades,
17.28: Thanksgiving perishes from the dead, as from one who doesn’t exist.
17.29: How great is the mercy of the Lord,
17.30: For humans are not capable of everything,
17.31: What is brighter than the sun? Yet even this can be eclipsed.
17.32: He looks upon the power of the height of heaven,

18.1: He who lives forever created the whole universe.
18.4: He has given power to declare his works to no one.
18.5: Who could measure the strength of his majesty?
18.6: As for the wondrous works of the Lord, it is not possible to take from them nor add to them,
18.7: When a man has finished, then he is just at the beginning.
18.8: What is mankind, and what purpose do they serve?
18.9: The number of man’s days at the most are a hundred years.
18.10: As a drop of water from the sea, and a pebble from the sand,
18.11: For this cause the Lord was patient over them,
18.12: He saw and perceived their end, that it is evil.
18.13: The mercy of a man is on his neighbor;
18.14: He has mercy on those who accept chastening,
18.15: My son, don’t add reproach to your good deeds,
18.16: Doesn’t the dew relieve the scorching heat?
18.17: Behold, isn’t a word better than a gift?
18.18: A fool is ungracious and abusive.
18.21: Humble yourself before you get sick.
18.22: Let nothing hinder you to pay your vow in due time.
18.23: Before you make a vow, prepare yourself.
18.24: Think about the wrath coming in the days of the end,
18.25: In the days of fullness remember the time of hunger.
18.26: From morning until evening, the time changes.
18.27: A wise man is cautious in everything.
18.28: Every man of understanding knows wisdom.
18.29: They who were of understanding in sayings also became wise themselves,
18.31: If you give fully to your soul the delight of her desire,
18.32: Don’t make merry in much luxury,
18.33: Don’t be made a beggar by banqueting with borrowed money

19.1: A worker who is a drunkard will not become rich.
19.2: Wine and women will make men of understanding go astray.
19.3: Decay and worms will have him as their heritage.
19.4: He who is hasty to trust is shallow-hearted.
19.5: He who rejoices in wickedness will be condemned.
19.6: He who hates gossip has less wickedness.
19.7: Never repeat what is told you,
19.8: Whether it is of friend or foe, don’t tell it.
19.9: For if he has heard you and observed you,
19.10: Have you heard something? Let it die with you.
19.11: A fool will travail in pain with a word,
19.12: As an arrow that sticks in the flesh of the thigh,
19.13: Question a friend; it may be he didn’t do it.
19.14: Question your neighbor; it may be he didn’t say it.
19.15: Question a friend; for many times there is slander.
19.16: There is one who slips, and not from the heart.
19.17: Reprove your neighbor before you threaten him;
19.20: All wisdom is the fear of the Lord.
19.22: The knowledge of wickedness is not wisdom.
19.23: There is a wickedness, and it is an abomination.
19.24: Better is one who has little understanding, and fears God,
19.25: There is an exquisite subtlety, and it is unjust.
19.26: There is one who does wickedly, who hangs down his head with mourning;
19.27: bowing down his face, and pretending to be deaf in one ear.
19.28: And if for lack of power he is hindered from sinning,
19.29: A man will be known by his appearance.

20.1: There is a reproof that is not timely;
20.2: How good is it to reprove, rather than to be angry.
20.4: As is the lust of a eunuch to deflower a virgin,
20.5: There is one who keeps silent and is found wise;
20.6: There is one who keeps silent, for he has no answer to make;
20.7: A wise man will be silent until his time has come,
20.8: He who uses many words will be abhorred.
20.9: There is a prosperity that a man finds in misfortunes;
20.10: There is a gift that will not profit you;
20.11: There are losses because of glory;
20.12: There is one who buys much for a little,
20.13: He who is wise in words will make himself beloved;
20.14: The gift of a fool will not profit you,
20.15: He will give little and insult much.
20.16: The fool will say, “I have no friend,
20.17: How often, and of how many, will he be laughed to scorn!
20.18: A slip on a pavement is better than a slip with the tongue.
20.19: A man without grace is a tale out of season.
20.20: A parable from a fool’s mouth will be rejected;
20.21: There is one who is hindered from sinning through lack.
20.22: There is one who destroys his soul through bashfulness.
20.23: There is one who for bashfulness makes promises to his friend;
20.24: A lie is an ugly blot on a person.
20.25: A thief is better than a man who is continually lying,
20.26: The destination of a liar is dishonor.
20.27: He who is wise in words will advance himself.
20.28: He who tills his land will raise his harvest high.
20.29: Favors and gifts blind the eyes of the wise,
20.30: Wisdom that is hidden, and treasure that is out of sight—
20.31: Better is a man who hides his folly

21.2: Flee from sin as from the face of a snake;
21.3: All iniquity is as a two-edged sword.
21.4: Terror and violence will waste away riches.
21.5: Supplication from a poor man’s mouth reaches to the ears of God,
21.6: One who hates reproof is in the path of the sinner.
21.7: He who is mighty in tongue is known far away;
21.8: He who builds his house with other men’s money
21.9: The congregation of wicked men is as a bundle of tow
21.10: The way of sinners is paved with stones;
21.11: He who keeps the law becomes master of its intent.
21.12: He who is not clever will not be instructed.
21.13: The knowledge of a wise man will be made to abound as a flood,
21.14: The inward parts of a fool are like a broken vessel.
21.15: If a man of knowledge hears a wise word,
21.16: The chatter of a fool is like a burden in the way,
21.17: The utterance of the prudent man will be sought for in the congregation.
21.18: As a house that is destroyed, so is wisdom to a fool.
21.19: Instruction is as fetters on the feet of an unwise man,
21.20: A fool lifts up his voice with laughter,
21.21: Instruction is to a prudent man as an ornament of gold,
21.22: The foot of a fool rushes into a house,
21.23: A foolish man peers into the door of a house,
21.24: It is rude for someone to listen at a door,
21.25: The lips of strangers will be grieved at these things,
21.26: The heart of fools is in their mouth,
21.27: When the ungodly curses an adversary,
21.28: A whisperer defiles his own soul,

22.1: A slothful man is compared to a stone that is defiled.
22.2: A slothful man is compared to the filth of a dunghill.
22.3: An undisciplined child is a disgrace to his father,
22.4: A prudent daughter will inherit a husband of her own.
22.5: She who is arrogant brings shame on father and husband.
22.6: Ill-timed conversation is like music in mourning,
22.7: He who teaches a fool is like one who glues potsherds together,
22.8: He who teaches a fool is as one who teaches a man who slumbers.
22.11: Weep for the dead, for he lacks light.
22.12: Mourning for the dead lasts seven days,
22.13: Don’t talk much with a foolish man,
22.14: What would be heavier than lead?
22.15: Sand, salt, and a mass of iron is easier to bear
22.16: Timber girded and bound into a building will not be released with shaking.
22.17: A heart settled upon a thoughtful understanding
22.18: Fences set on a high place will not stand against the wind;
22.19: He who pricks the eye will make tears fall.
22.20: Whoever casts a stone at birds scares them away.
22.21: If you have drawn a sword against a friend, don’t despair,
22.22: If you have opened your mouth against a friend, don’t be afraid,
22.23: Gain trust with your neighbor in his poverty,
22.24: Before fire is the vapor and smoke of a furnace,
22.25: I won’t be ashamed to shelter a friend.
22.26: If any evil happens to me because of him,
22.27: Who will set a watch over my mouth,

23.1: O Lord, Father and Master of my life,
23.2: Who will set scourges over my thought,
23.3: Otherwise my errors might be multiplied,
23.4: O Lord, Father and God of my life,
23.5: and turn away evil desire from me.

23.8: The sinner will be overpowered through his lips.
23.9: Don’t accustom your mouth to an oath,
23.10: for as a servant who is continually scourged will not lack bruises,
23.11: A man of many oaths will be filled with iniquity.
23.12: There is a manner of speech that is clothed with death.
23.13: Don’t accustom your mouth to gross rudeness,
23.14: Remember your father and your mother,
23.15: A man who is accustomed to abusive language
23.16: Two sorts of people multiply sins,

23.18: A man who goes astray from his own marriage bed
23.19: The eyes of men are his terror.
23.20: All things were known to him before they were created,

23.23: For first, she was disobedient in the law of the Most High.
23.24: She shall be brought out into the congregation.

24.1: Wisdom will praise her own soul,
24.2: She will open her mouth in the congregation of the Most High,
24.3: “I came out of the mouth of the Most High,
24.5: Alone I surrounded the circuit of heaven,
24.6: In the waves of the sea, and in all the earth,
24.7: With all these I sought rest.
24.8: Then the Creator of all things gave me a command.
24.9: He created me from the beginning, before the ages.
24.10: In the holy tabernacle, I ministered before him.
24.11: In the beloved city, likewise he gave me rest.
24.12: I took root in a people that was honored,
24.13: I was exalted like a cedar in Lebanon,
24.14: I was exalted like a palm tree on the sea shore,
24.15: Like cinnamon and aspalathus, I have given a scent to perfumes.
24.16: Like the terebinth, I stretched out my branches.
24.17: Like the vine, I put forth grace.
24.19: “Come to me, all you who desire me,
24.20: For my memory is sweeter than honey,
24.21: Those who eat me will be hungry for more.
24.22: He who obeys me will not be ashamed.
24.23: All these things are the book of the covenant of the Most High God,
24.25: It is he who makes wisdom abundant, as Pishon,
24.26: He makes understanding full as the Euphrates,
24.27: who makes instruction shine forth as the light,
24.28: The first man didn’t know her perfectly.
24.29: For her thoughts are filled from the sea,
24.30: I came out as a canal stream from a river,
24.31: I said, “I will water my garden,
24.32: I will yet bring instruction to light as the morning,
24.33: I will continue to pour out teaching like prophecy,
24.34: See that I have not labored for myself only,

25.2: But my soul hates three sorts of people,
25.3: If you gathered nothing in your youth,
25.4: How beautiful a thing is judgment in the gray-haired,
25.5: How beautiful is the wisdom of old men,
25.6: Much experience is the crown of the aged.
25.7: There are nine things that I have thought of, and in my heart counted happy,
25.8: Happy is he who dwells with a wife of understanding,
25.9: Happy is he who has found prudence,
25.10: How great is he who has found wisdom!
25.11: The fear of the Lord surpasses all things.
25.13: Any wound but a wound of the heart!
25.14: Any calamity but a calamity from those who hate me!
25.15: There is no venom worse than a snake’s venom.
25.16: I would rather dwell with a lion and a dragon
25.17: The wickedness of a woman changes her appearance,
25.18: Her husband will sit among his neighbors,
25.19: All malice is small compared to the malice of a woman.
25.20: As walking up a sandy hill is to the feet of the aged,
25.21: Don’t be ensnared by a woman’s beauty.
25.22: There is anger, impudence, and great reproach
25.23: A wicked woman is abasement of heart,
25.24: The beginning of sin came from a woman.
25.26: If she doesn’t go as you direct,

26.1: Happy is the husband of a good wife.
26.2: A faithful wife gives joy to her husband.
26.3: A good wife is a great gift.
26.4: Whether a man is rich or poor,
26.5: Of three things my heart was afraid,
26.6: A grief of heart and sorrow is a woman who is jealous of another woman.
26.7: A wicked woman is like a chafing yoke.
26.8: A drunken woman causes great wrath.
26.9: The fornication of a woman is in the lifting up of her eyes;
26.10: Keep strict watch on a headstrong daughter,
26.11: Watch out for an impudent eye,
26.12: She will open her mouth like a thirsty traveller,
26.13: The grace of a wife will delight her husband.
26.14: A silent woman is a gift of the Lord.
26.15: A modest woman is grace upon grace.
26.16: As the sun when it arises in the highest places of the Lord,
26.17: As the lamp that shines upon the holy lampstand,
26.18: As the golden pillars are upon a base of silver,
26.28: For two things my heart is grieved,
26.29: It is difficult for a merchant to keep himself from wrong doing,

27.2: As a nail will stick fast between the joinings of stones,
27.3: Unless a person holds on diligently to the fear of the Lord,
27.4: In the shaking of a sieve, the refuse remains,
27.5: The furnace tests the potter’s vessels;
27.6: The fruit of a tree discloses its cultivation,
27.7: Praise no man before you hear his thoughts,
27.8: If you follow righteousness, you will obtain it,
27.9: Birds will return to their own kind,
27.10: The lion lies in wait for prey.
27.11: The discourse of a godly man is always wise,
27.12: Limit your time among people void of understanding,
27.13: The talk of fools is offensive.
27.14: Their talk with much swearing makes hair stand upright.
27.15: The strife of the proud leads to bloodshed.
27.16: He who reveals secrets destroys trust,
27.17: Love a friend, and keep faith with him;
27.18: for as a man has destroyed his enemy,
27.19: As a bird which you have released out of your hand,
27.20: Don’t pursue him, for he has gone far away,
27.21: For a wound may be bound up, and after abuse there may be reconciliation;
27.22: One who winks the eye contrives evil things;
27.23: When you are present, he will speak sweetly,
27.24: I have hated many things, but nothing like him.
27.25: One who casts a stone straight up casts it on his own head.
27.26: He who digs a pit will fall into it.
27.27: He who does evil things, they will roll back upon him,
27.28: Mockery and reproach are from the arrogant.
27.29: Those who rejoice at the fall of the godly will be caught in a snare.
27.30: Wrath and anger, these also are abominations.

28.1: He who takes vengeance will find vengeance from the Lord,
28.2: Forgive your neighbor the hurt that he has done,
28.3: Does anyone harbor anger against another
28.4: Upon a man like himself he has no mercy,
28.5: He himself, being flesh, nourishes wrath.
28.6: Remember your last end, and stop enmity.
28.7: Remember the commandments, and don’t be angry with your neighbor.
28.8: Abstain from strife, and you will diminish your sins,
28.9: A man who is a sinner will trouble friends
28.10: As is the fuel of the fire, so it will burn;
28.11: A contention begun in haste kindles a fire;
28.12: If you blow on a spark, it will burn;
28.15: A slanderer has cast out brave women
28.16: He who listens to it will not find rest,
28.17: The stroke of a whip makes a mark in the flesh,
28.18: Many have fallen by the edge of the sword,
28.19: Happy is he who is sheltered from it,
28.20: For its yoke is a yoke of iron,
28.21: Its death is an evil death,
28.22: It will not have rule over godly men.
28.23: Those who forsake the Lord will fall into it.
28.24: As you hedge your possession about with thorns,
28.25: so make a balance and a weight for your words,
28.26: Take heed lest you slip with it,

29.1: He who shows mercy will lend to his neighbor.
29.2: Lend to your neighbor in time of his need.
29.3: Confirm your word, and keep faith with him;
29.4: Many have considered a loan to be a windfall,
29.5: Until he has received, he will kiss a man’s hands.
29.6: If he prevails, the creditor will hardly receive half;
29.7: Many on account of fraud have turned away.
29.8: However be patient with a man in poor estate.
29.9: Help a poor man for the commandment’s sake.
29.10: Lose your money for a brother and a friend.
29.11: Allocate your treasure according to the commandments of the Most High
29.12: Store up almsgiving in your store-chambers
29.13: It will fight for you against your enemy
29.14: A good man will be surety for his neighbor.
29.15: Don’t forget the kindness of your guarantor,
29.16: A sinner will waste the property of his guarantor.
29.17: He who is thankless will fail him who delivered him.
29.18: Being surety has undone many who were prospering
29.19: A sinner who falls into suretiship and undertakes contracts for work
29.20: Help your neighbor according to your power,
29.21: The essentials of life are water, bread,
29.22: Better is the life of a poor man under a shelter of logs
29.23: With little or with much, be well satisfied.
29.24: It is a miserable life to go from house to house.
29.25: You will entertain, serve drinks, and have no thanks.
29.26: “Come here, you sojourner, set a table,
29.27: “Leave, you sojourner, for an honored guest is here.
29.28: These things are grievous to a man of understanding:

30.1: He who loves his son will continue to lay stripes upon him,
30.2: He who chastises his son will have profit from him,
30.3: He who teaches his son will provoke his enemy to jealousy.
30.4: His father dies, and is as though he had not died;
30.5: In his life, he saw his son and rejoiced.
30.6: He left behind him an avenger against his enemies,
30.7: He who makes too much of his son will bind up his wounds.
30.9: Pamper your child, and he will make you afraid.
30.10: Don’t laugh with him, lest you have sorrow with him,
30.11: Give him no liberty in his youth,
30.12: Bow down his neck in his youth,
30.13: Chastise your son, and give him work,
30.14: Better is a poor man who is healthy and fit,
30.15: Health and fitness are better than all gold,
30.16: There is no wealth better than health of body.
30.17: Death is better than a bitter life,
30.18: Good things poured out upon a mouth that is closed
30.19: What does an offering profit an idol?
30.20: seeing with his eyes and groaning,
30.21: Don’t give your soul to sorrow.
30.22: Gladness of heart is the life of a man.
30.23: Love your own soul, and comfort your heart.
30.25: Those who are cheerful and merry

31.1: Wakefulness that comes from riches consumes the flesh,
31.3: A rich man toils in gathering money together.
31.4: A poor man toils in lack of substance.
31.5: He who loves gold won’t be justified.
31.6: Many have been given over to ruin for the sake of gold.
31.7: It is a stumbling block to those who sacrifice to it.
31.8: Blessed is the rich person who is found blameless,
31.9: Who is he, that we may call him blessed?
31.10: Who has been tried by it, and found perfect?
31.11: His prosperity will be made sure.
31.12: Do you sit at a great table? Don’t be greedy there.
31.13: Remember that a greedy eye is a wicked thing.
31.14: Don’t stretch your hand wherever it looks.
31.15: Consider your neighbor’s feelings by your own.
31.16: Eat like a human being those things which are set before you.
31.17: Be first to stop for manners’ sake.
31.18: And if you sit among many,
31.19: How sufficient to a well-mannered man is a very little.
31.20: Healthy sleep comes from moderate eating.
31.21: And if you have been forced to eat,
31.22: Hear me, my son, and don’t despise me,
31.23: People bless him who is liberal with his food.
31.24: The city will murmur at him who is a stingy with his food.
31.25: Don’t show yourself valiant in wine,
31.26: The furnace tests the temper of steel by dipping;
31.27: Wine is as good as life to men,
31.28: Wine drunk in season and in moderation
31.29: Wine drunk excessively is bitterness of soul,
31.30: Drunkenness increases the rage of a fool to his hurt.
31.31: Don’t rebuke your neighbor at a banquet of wine.

32.1: Have they made you ruler of a feast?
32.2: And when you have done all your duties, take your place,
32.3: Speak, you who are older, for it’s your right, but with sound knowledge;
32.4: Don’t pour out talk where there is a performance of music.
32.5: As a ruby signet in a setting of gold,
32.6: As an emerald signet in a work of gold,
32.7: Speak, young man, if you are obliged to,
32.8: Sum up your speech, many things in few words.
32.9: When among great men, don’t behave as their equal.
32.11: Rise up in good time, and don’t be last.
32.12: Amuse yourself there and do what is in your heart.
32.13: For these things bless your Maker,
32.14: He who fears the Lord will receive discipline.
32.15: He who seeks the law shall be filled with it,
32.16: Those who fear the Lord will find true judgment,
32.18: A sensible person won’t neglect a thought.
32.20: Don’t go in a way of conflict.
32.21: Don’t be overconfident on a smooth road.
32.23: In every work guard your own soul,
32.24: He who believes the law gives heed to the commandment.

33.1: No evil will happen to him who fears the Lord,
33.2: A wise man will not hate the law,
33.3: A man of understanding will put his trust in the law.
33.4: Prepare your speech, and so you will be heard.
33.5: The heart of a fool is like a cartwheel.
33.6: A stallion horse is like a mocking friend.
33.7: Why does one day excel another,
33.8: They were distinguished by the Lord’s knowledge,
33.9: Some of them he exalted and hallowed,
33.10: And all men are from the ground.
33.11: In the abundance of his knowledge the Lord distinguished them,
33.12: Some of them he blessed and exalted,
33.13: As the clay of the potter in his hand,
33.14: Good is the opposite of evil,
33.15: Look upon all the works of the Most High like this,
33.16: I was the last on watch,
33.17: By the Lord’s blessing I arrived before them,
33.18: Consider that I labored not for myself alone,
33.19: Hear me, you great men of the people,
33.20: To son and wife, to brother and friend,
33.21: While you still live and breath is in you,
33.22: For it is better that your children should ask from you
33.24: In the day that you end the days of your life,
33.25: Fodder, a stick, and burdens are for a donkey.
33.26: Set your slave to work, and you will find rest.
33.27: Yoke and whip will bow the neck.
33.28: Send him to labor, that he not be idle,
33.29: Set him to work, as is fit for him.
33.31: If you have a slave, treat him like yourself,
33.32: If you have a slave, treat him like yourself.
33.33: which way will you go to seek him?

34.1: Vain and false hopes are for a man void of understanding.
34.2: As one who grasps at a shadow and follows after the wind,
34.3: The vision of dreams is a reflection,
34.4: From an unclean thing what can be cleansed?
34.5: Divinations, and soothsayings, and dreams, are vain.
34.6: If they are not sent in a visitation from the Most High,
34.7: For dreams have led many astray.
34.8: Without lying the law will be fulfilled.
34.9: A well-instructed man knows many things.
34.10: He who has no experience knows few things.
34.11: I have seen many things in my travels.
34.12: I was often in danger even to death.
34.13: The spirit of those who fear the Lord will live,
34.14: Whoever fears the Lord won’t be afraid, and won’t be a coward,
34.15: Blessed is the soul of him who fears the Lord.
34.16: The eyes of the Lord are on those who love him,
34.17: He raises up the soul, and enlightens the eyes.
34.18: He who sacrifices a thing wrongfully gotten, his offering is made in mockery.
34.19: The Most High has no pleasure in the offerings of the ungodly,
34.20: Like one who kills a son before his father’s eyes
34.21: The bread of the needy is the life of the poor.
34.22: Like one who murders his neighbor is he who takes away his living.
34.23: When one builds, and another pulls down,
34.24: When one prays, and another curses,
34.25: He who washes himself after touching a dead body, and touches it again,
34.26: Even so a man fasting for his sins,

35.1: He who keeps the law multiplies offerings.
35.2: He who returns a kindness offers fine flour.
35.3: To depart from wickedness pleases the Lord.
35.4: See that you don’t appear in the presence of the Lord empty.
35.5: For all these things are done because of the commandment.
35.6: The offering of the righteous enriches the altar.
35.7: The sacrifice of a righteous man is acceptable.
35.9: In every gift show a cheerful countenance,
35.10: Give to the Most High according as he has given.
35.12: Don’t plan to bribe him with gifts, for he will not receive them.
35.13: He won’t accept any person against a poor man.
35.14: He will in no way despise the supplication of the fatherless
35.15: Don’t the tears of the widow run down her cheek?
35.16: He who serves God according to his good pleasure will be accepted.
35.17: The prayer of the humble pierces the clouds.
35.18: And the Lord will not be slack, neither will he be patient toward them,
35.19: until he has rendered to every man according to his deeds,
35.20: Mercy is as welcome in the time of his affliction,

36.1: Have mercy upon us, O Lord the God of all, and look at us with favor;
36.2: and send your fear upon all the nations.
36.3: Lift up your hand against the foreign nations
36.4: As you showed your holiness in us before them,
36.5: Let them know you, as we also have known you,
36.6: Show new signs, and work various wonders.
36.7: Raise up indignation and pour out wrath.
36.8: Hasten the time and remember your oath.
36.9: Let him who escapes be devoured by raging fire.
36.10: Crush the heads of the rulers of the enemies
36.11: Gather all the tribes of Jacob together,
36.12: O Lord, have mercy upon the people that is called by your name,
36.13: Have compassion upon the city of your sanctuary,
36.15: Give testimony to those who were your creatures in the beginning,
36.16: Reward those who wait for you,
36.17: Listen, O Lord, to the prayer of your servants,
36.18: The belly will eat any food,
36.19: The mouth tastes meats taken in hunting,
36.20: A contrary heart will cause heaviness.
36.21: A woman will receive any man,
36.22: The beauty of a woman cheers the countenance.
36.23: If kindness and humility are on her tongue,
36.24: He who gets a wife gets his richest treasure,
36.25: Where no hedge is, the property will be plundered.
36.26: For who would trust a nimble robber who skips from city to city?

37.1: Every friend will say, “I also am his friend”;
37.2: Isn’t there a grief in it even to death
37.3: O wicked imagination, why were you formed
37.4: There is a companion who rejoices in the gladness of a friend,
37.5: There is a companion who for the belly’s sake labors with his friend,
37.6: Don’t forget a friend in your soul.
37.8: Let your soul beware of a counselor,
37.9: and say to you, “Your way is good.”
37.10: Don’t take counsel with one who looks askance at you.
37.11: Don’t consult with a woman about her rival,
37.12: But rather be continually with a godly man,
37.13: Make the counsel of your heart stand,
37.14: For a man’s soul is sometimes inclined to inform him
37.15: Above all this ask the Most High
37.16: Let reason be the beginning of every work.
37.17: As a token of the changing of the heart,
37.18: four kinds of things rise up:
37.19: There is one who is clever and the instructor of many,
37.20: There is one who is subtle in words, and is hated.
37.21: For grace was not given to him from the Lord,
37.22: There is one who is wise to his own soul;
37.23: A wise man will instruct his own people.
37.24: A wise man will be filled with blessing.
37.25: The life of a man is counted by days.
37.26: The wise man will inherit confidence among his people.
37.27: My son, test your soul in your life.
37.28: For not all things are profitable for all men.
37.29: Don’t be insatiable in any luxury.
37.31: Because of gluttony, many have perished,

38.1: Honor a physician according to your need with the honors due to him,
38.2: For healing comes from the Most High,
38.3: The skill of the physician will lift up his head.
38.4: The Lord created medicines out of the earth.
38.5: Wasn’t water made sweet with wood,
38.8: With these, the pharmacist makes a mixture.
38.9: My son, in your sickness don’t be negligent,
38.10: Put away wrong doing, and direct your hands in righteousness.
38.11: Give a sweet savor and a memorial of fine flour,
38.12: Then give place to the physician, for truly the Lord has created him.
38.13: There is a time when recovery is in their hands.
38.14: For they also shall ask the Lord
38.15: He who sins before his Maker,
38.16: My son, let your tears fall over the dead,
38.17: Make bitter weeping and make passionate wailing.
38.20: Don’t give your heart to sorrow.
38.21: Don’t forget it, for there is no returning again.
38.22: Remember his end, for so also will yours be:
38.23: When the dead is at rest, let his remembrance rest.
38.24: The wisdom of the scribe comes by the opportunity of leisure.
38.25: How could he become wise who holds the plow,
38.26: He will set his heart upon turning his furrows.
38.27: So is every craftsman and master artisan
38.28: So too is the smith sitting by the anvil
38.29: So is the potter sitting at his work
38.30: He will fashion the clay with his arm
38.31: All these put their trust in their hands.
38.32: Without these no city would be inhabited.
38.33: They won’t be sought for in the council of the people.
38.34: But they will maintain the fabric of the age.

39.1: Not so he who has applied his soul
39.2: He will keep the sayings of the men of renown
39.3: He will seek out the hidden meaning of proverbs
39.4: He will serve among great men
39.5: He will apply his heart to return early to the Lord who made him,
39.7: He will direct his counsel and knowledge,
39.8: He will show the instruction which he has been taught
39.11: If he continues, he will leave a greater name than a thousand.
39.12: Yet more I will utter, which I have thought about.
39.13: Listen to me, you holy children,
39.14: Give a sweet fragrance like frankincense.
39.16: All the works of the Lord are exceedingly good,
39.17: No one can say, “What is this?” “Why is that?”
39.18: At his command all his good pleasure is fulfilled.
39.19: The works of all flesh are before him.
39.20: He sees from everlasting to everlasting.
39.21: No one can say, “What is this?” “Why is that?”
39.22: His blessing covered the dry land as a river
39.23: As he has made the waters salty,
39.24: His ways are plain to the holy.
39.25: Good things are created from the beginning for the good.
39.26: The main things necessary for the life of man
39.27: All these things are for good to the godly,
39.28: There are winds that are created for vengeance,
39.31: They will rejoice in his commandment,
39.32: Therefore from the beginning I was convinced,
39.33: All the works of the Lord are good.
39.34: No one can say, “This is worse than that,”
39.35: Now with all your hearts and voices, sing praises

40.1: Great travail is created for every man.
40.2: The expectation of things to come, and the day of death,
40.3: From him who sits on a throne of glory,
40.4: from him who wears purple and a crown,
40.5: there is wrath, jealousy, trouble, unrest,
40.6: He gets little or no rest,
40.7: In the very time of his deliverance, he awakens,
40.8: To all creatures, human and animal,
40.10: All these things were created for the wicked,
40.11: All things that are of the earth turn to the earth again.
40.12: All bribery and injustice will be blotted out.
40.13: The goods of the unjust will be dried up like a river,
40.14: In opening his hands, a man will be made glad;
40.15: The children of the ungodly won’t grow many branches,
40.16: The reeds by every water or river bank
40.17: Kindness is like a garden of blessings.
40.18: The life of one who labors and is content will be made sweet.
40.19: Children and the building of a city establish a name.
40.20: Wine and music rejoice the heart.
40.21: The pipe and the lute make pleasant melody.
40.22: Your eye desires grace and beauty,
40.23: A friend and a companion is always welcome,
40.24: Relatives and helpers are for a time of affliction,
40.25: Gold and silver will make the foot stand sure,
40.26: Riches and strength will lift up the heart.
40.27: The fear of the Lord is like a garden of blessing
40.28: My son, don’t lead a beggar’s life.
40.29: A man who looks to the table of another,
40.30: Begging will be sweet in the mouth of the shameless,

41.1: O death, how bitter is the memory of you to a man who is at peace in his possessions,
41.2: O death, your sentence is acceptable to a man who is needy and who fails in strength,
41.3: Don’t be afraid of the sentence of death.
41.4: And why do you refuse when it is the good pleasure of the Most High?
41.5: The children of sinners are abominable children
41.6: The inheritance of sinners’ children will perish
41.7: Children will complain of an ungodly father,
41.9: If you are born, you will be born to a curse.
41.10: All things that are of the earth will go back to the earth;
41.11: The mourning of men is about their bodies;
41.13: A good life has its number of days,
41.14: My children, follow instruction in peace.
41.15: Better is a man who hides his foolishness
41.16: Therefore show respect for my words;
41.17: Be ashamed of sexual immorality before father and mother,
41.18: of an offense before a judge and ruler,
41.19: and of theft in the place where you sojourn.
41.20: of silence before those who greet you,
41.21: of turning away your face from a kinsman,
41.22: of meddling with his maid—and don’t come near her bed,
41.23: of repeating and speaking what you have heard,
41.24: So you will be ashamed of the right things

42.1: Don’t be ashamed of these things,
42.2: of the law of the Most High and his covenant,
42.3: of reckoning with a partner and with travellers,
42.4: of exactness of scales and weights,
42.6: A seal is good where an evil wife is.
42.7: Whatever you hand over, let it be by number and weight.
42.8: Don’t be ashamed to instruct the unwise and foolish,
42.9: A daughter is a secret cause of wakefulness to a father.
42.10: in her virginity, lest she should be defiled and be with child in her father’s house;
42.11: Keep a strict watch over a headstrong daughter,
42.12: Don’t gaze at every beautiful body.
42.13: For from garments comes a moth,
42.14: Better is the wickedness of a man than a pleasant woman,
42.15: I will make mention now of the works of the Lord,
42.16: The sun that gives light looks at all things.
42.17: The Lord has not given power to the saints to declare all his marvelous works,
42.18: He searches out the deep and the heart.
42.19: He declares the things that are past and the things that shall be,
42.21: He has ordered the mighty works of his wisdom.
42.22: How desirable are all his works!
42.23: All these things live and remain forever in all manner of uses.
42.24: All things are in pairs, one opposite the other.
42.25: One thing establishes the good things of another.

43.1: The pride of the heavenly heights is the clear sky,
43.2: The sun, when it appears, bringing tidings as it rises,
43.3: At noon, it dries up the land.
43.4: A man tending a furnace is in burning heat,
43.5: Great is the Lord who made it.
43.6: The moon marks the changing seasons,
43.7: From the moon is the sign of feast days,
43.8: The month is called after its name,
43.9: the beauty of heaven, the glory of the stars,
43.10: At the word of the Holy One, they will stand in due order.
43.11: Look at the rainbow, and praise him who made it.
43.12: It encircles the sky with its glorious circle.
43.13: By his commandment, he makes the snow fall
43.15: By his mighty power, he makes the clouds strong
43.16: At his appearing, the mountains will be shaken.
43.17: The voice of his thunder rebukes the earth.
43.18: The eye is dazzled at the beauty of its whiteness.
43.19: He also pours out frost on the earth like salt.
43.21: It will devour the mountains, burn up the wilderness,
43.22: A mist coming speedily heals all things.
43.23: By his counsel, he has calmed the deep
43.24: Those who sail on the sea tell of its dangers.
43.25: There are also those strange and wondrous works in it—
43.26: Because of him, his messengers succeed.
43.27: We may say many things, but couldn’t say enough.
43.28: How could we have strength to glorify him?
43.29: The Lord is awesome and exceedingly great!
43.30: Glorify the Lord and exalt him as much as you can!
43.31: Who has seen him, that he may describe him?
43.32: Many things greater than these are hidden,
43.33: For the Lord made all things.

44.1: Let us now praise famous men,
44.2: The Lord created great glory in them—
44.4: leaders of the people by their counsels,
44.7: All these were honored in their generations,
44.8: Some of them have left a name behind them,
44.9: But of others, there is no memory.
44.10: But these were men of mercy,
44.11: A good inheritance remains with their offspring.
44.14: Their bodies were buried in peace.
44.16: Enoch pleased the Lord, and was taken up,
44.17: Noah was found perfect and righteous.
44.18: Everlasting covenants were made with him,
44.19: Abraham was a great father of a multitude of nations.
44.20: who kept the law of the Most High,
44.21: Therefore he assured him by an oath
44.22: In Isaac also, he established the same assurance for Abraham his father’s sake,
44.23: He made it rest upon the head of Jacob.

45.1: He brought out of him a man of mercy,
45.2: He made him equal to the glory of the saints,
45.3: By his words he caused the wonders to cease.
45.4: He sanctified him in his faithfulness and meekness.
45.5: He made him to hear his voice,
45.6: He exalted Aaron, a holy man like Moses,
45.7: He established an everlasting covenant with him,
45.8: He clothed him in perfect splendor,
45.10: with a holy garment, with gold, blue, and purple, the work of the embroiderer;
45.11: with twisted scarlet, the work of the craftsman;
45.12: with a crown of gold upon the mitre, having engraved on it, as on a signet, “HOLINESS”,
45.13: Before him there never have been anything like it.
45.14: His sacrifices shall be wholly burned,
45.16: He chose him out of all living
45.17: He gave to him in his commandments,
45.19: The Lord saw it, and it displeased him.
45.21: For they eat the sacrifices of the Lord,
45.22: However, in the land of the people, he has no inheritance,
45.23: Phinehas the son of Eleazar is the third in glory,
45.24: Therefore, a covenant of peace was established for him,
45.25: Also he made a covenant with David the son of Jesse, of the tribe of Judah.
45.26: May God give you wisdom in your heart

46.1: Joshua the son of Nun was valiant in war,
46.2: How he was glorified in the lifting up his hands,
46.3: Who before him stood so firm?
46.4: Didn’t the sun go back by his hand?
46.5: He called upon the Most High, the Mighty One,
46.7: Also in the time of Moses, he did a work of mercy—
46.8: And of six hundred thousand people on foot, they two alone were preserved
46.9: The Lord gave strength to Caleb,
46.10: that all the children of Israel might see that it is good to follow the Lord.
46.11: Also the judges, every one by his name,
46.12: May their bones flourish again out of their place.
46.13: Samuel, the prophet of the Lord, loved by his Lord,
46.14: By the law of the Lord he judged the congregation,
46.15: By his faithfulness he was proved to be a prophet.
46.16: When his enemies pressed on him on every side,
46.17: Then the Lord thundered from heaven.
46.18: He utterly destroyed the rulers of the Tyrians
46.19: Before the time of his age-long sleep,
46.20: Even after he fell asleep, he prophesied,

47.2: As is the fat when it is separated from the peace offering,
47.3: He played with lions as with kids,
47.4: In his youth didn’t he kill a giant,
47.5: For he called upon the Most High Lord,
47.6: So they glorified him for his tens of thousands,
47.7: For he destroyed the enemies on every side,
47.8: In every work of his he gave thanks to the Holy One Most High with words of glory.
47.9: He set singers before the altar,
47.10: He gave beauty to the feasts,
47.11: The Lord took away his sins,
47.12: After him a wise son rose up,
47.13: Solomon reigned in days of peace.
47.14: How wise you were made in your youth,
47.16: Your name reached to the far away islands,
47.18: By the name of the Lord God,
47.19: You bowed your loins to women,
47.22: But the Lord will never forsake his mercy.
47.23: So Solomon rested with his fathers.
47.25: For they sought out all manner of wickedness,

48.1: Then Elijah arose, the prophet like fire.
48.2: He brought a famine upon them,
48.3: By the word of the Lord he shut up the heavens.
48.4: How you were glorified, O Elijah, in your wondrous deeds!
48.5: You raised up a dead man from death,
48.6: You brought down kings to destruction,
48.9: You were taken up in a tempest of fire,
48.10: You were recorded for reproofs in their seasons,
48.11: Blessed are those who saw you,
48.12: Elijah was wrapped in a whirlwind.
48.13: Nothing was too hard for him.
48.14: As in his life he did wonders,
48.15: For all this the people didn’t repent.
48.16: Some of them did that which was right,
48.19: Then their hearts and their hands were shaken,
48.20: But they called upon the Lord who is merciful,
48.21: He struck the camp of the Assyrians,
48.22: For Hezekiah did that which was pleasing to the Lord,
48.23: In his days the sun went backward.
48.24: He saw by an excellent spirit what would come to pass in the future;
48.25: He showed the things that would happen through the end of time,

49.1: The memory of Josiah is like the composition of incense
49.2: He did what was right in the reforming of the people,
49.3: He set his heart right toward the Lord.
49.5: They gave their power to others,
49.6: They set the chosen city of the sanctuary on fire
49.8: Ezekiel saw the vision of glory,
49.9: For truly he remembered the enemies in rainstorm,
49.12: So was Jesus the son of Josedek,
49.13: Also of Nehemiah the memory is great.
49.14: No man was created upon the earth like Enoch,
49.15: Nor was there a man born like Joseph,
49.16: Shem and Seth were honored among men,

50.1: It was Simon, the son of Onias, the high priest,
50.2: The foundation was built by him to the height of the double walls,
50.3: In his days, a water cistern was dug,
50.4: He planned to save his people from ruin,
50.5: How glorious he was when the people gathered around him
50.6: He was like the morning star among clouds,
50.7: like the sun shining on the temple of the Most High,
50.8: like roses in the days of first fruits,
50.9: like fire and incense in the censer,
50.10: like an olive tree loaded with fruit,
50.11: When he put on his glorious robe,
50.12: When he received the portions out of the priests’ hands,
50.13: All the sons of Aaron in their glory,
50.14: Finishing the service at the altars,
50.15: he stretched out his hand to the cup of libation,
50.16: Then the sons of Aaron shouted.
50.17: Then all the people together hurried,
50.18: The singers also praised him with their voices.
50.19: And the people implored the Lord Most High,
50.20: Then he went down, and lifted up his hands
50.21: He bowed himself down in worship the second time,
50.22: Now bless the God of all,
50.23: May he grant us joyfulness of heart,
50.24: to entrust his mercy with us,
50.25: With two nations my soul is vexed,
50.26: Those who sit on the mountain of Samaria, the Philistines,
50.27: I have written in this book the instruction of understanding and knowledge,
50.28: Blessed is he who will exercise these things.
50.29: For if he does them, he will be strong in all things,

51.1: I will give thanks to you, O Lord, O King,
51.2: for you have been my protector and helper,
51.3: and delivered me, according to the abundance of your mercy and of your name,
51.4: from the choking of a fire on every side,
51.5: out of the depth of the belly of Hades,
51.6: the slander of an unrighteous tongue to the king.
51.7: They surrounded me on every side.
51.8: Then I remembered your mercy, O Lord,
51.9: I lifted up my prayer from the earth,
51.10: I called upon the Lord, the Father of my Lord,
51.11: I will praise your name continually.
51.14: Before the temple I asked for her.
51.15: From the first flower to the ripening grape my heart delighted in her.
51.16: I inclined my ear a little, and received her,
51.18: For I determined to practice her.
51.19: My soul has wrestled with her.
51.20: I directed my soul to her.
51.21: My belly also was troubled to seek her.
51.22: The Lord gave me a tongue for my reward.
51.23: Draw near to me, all you who are uneducated,
51.24: Why therefore are you all lacking in these things,
51.25: I opened my mouth and spoke,
51.26: Put your neck under the yoke,
51.28: Get instruction with a great sum of silver,
51.29: May your soul rejoice in his mercy,
51.30: Work your work before the time comes,
